div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.div:
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE, MONDAY, JANUARY 29. 1996.
OUR SPECIAL CABLES. THE ELECTIONS. Mk. HALDANE AND THE ARMY. (Gazette’s Special Service.) London, Monday, Jan. 29. To day the Government gains are seven and the Unionist one. The Government undergoes no change in sixteen constituencies and the Unionist in six. Mr. Walter Long has been elected. ( Gazette’s Special Service ) ^London, Monday, Jan. 29. Mr. Haldane, speaking at Edinburgh, laid stress on the fact that what we want in the army is more "thinking” officers in the cavalry and line regiments. He looks to the universities to suppiy these. Commenting on the magnificent majority gained by the Government, and the power it conveyed, he said that what they wanted was ideas. LOCAL AND GENERAL. Mariout Diatrict. Miralai Hopkins »n Bey, Commandant of the Alexandria City Police, left yesterday for a five days’ inspection of the Mariout district Stray Dogs. Stray and ownerless dogs found in the Ein Shams district of Cairo at dawn to morrow, 'and in Abbassieh at dawn on Wednesday, will be poisoned by the police. A New Departure. Messrs. Gilliam and Walters, representing the British American Tobacco Co., Limited, Cecil Chambers, London, have engaged premi- ses in Cairo and will shortly start work. Hashish Seizure. Two sacks of hashish were seized by the Coast Guards on Saturday night as they were being drawn through the water towards the coast at Gabbari by means of ropes from some ship in the harbour. The would-be smugglers escaped. The Weather. A fairly strong gale prevailed yesterday and on Saturday night at Alexandria, and a high sea ruled. The Coast Guard Nesseem was caught in the gale off the coast on Saturday night and had one of her boats carried away, besides her bowsprit She had to put in to Aboukir for shelter. The Kaiser’s Birthday. Saturday being the 47th anniversary of the Emperor William’s birthday many buildings in Cairo flew the German flag. A service was held in the German Church at 10 a.m. at which Dr. Rucker Jenisch, Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General; Dr. Gumprecht, Consul; and all the staff of the Agency and Consulate were present. A reception was held at the Agency and later in the morning Dr. Rucker Jenisch called on Boutros Pacha Ghali, Minis ter for Foreign Affairs, who returned the call shortly afterwards. Iu the evening a grand tanquet was held at the Continental Hotel at which over a hundred members of the German Colony were present. Egyptian Directories. The directories of Mr. Stefano G. Poffandi and of Messrs. Rizzo and Co. for 1906 have made their appearance. Considering the great difficulties That have to be encountered in this country in keeping a directory np to date and ferreting out all the changes of address, estab- lishments of new firms and companies, and the hundred and one other odds and ends that go to make up a reliable work of the kind, we must say that these two works are excellent. With the exception of the G unison Directory, which is only a partial one, there are no other works of the kind in Egypt, and both Mr. Poffandi and Messrs. Rizzo & Co.’s books deserve to be on the desk of every business man in Egypt.
DEATH OF SIR E. PALMER. PROMINENT LOCAL FINANCIER. SKETCH OF SUCCESSFUL CAREER. MENA HOUSE GYMKHANA. The Gymkhaua to be held at Mena House Hotel on Tuesday, 6th February, promises to be a great success. Officials from the country who are taking advantage of the Beyram holidays are beginning to send in their ponies to Mena House Hotel, whose management have made special arrangements to provide stalls for that purpose. Id order to enable residents to take part in the donkey races the manage- ment have also made arrangements to keep a large number of donkeys on the race course which can be hired there at the rate of 5 piastres a-boad. The bookings for the ladies’ horse race (distance three furlongs) are coming in fast, and the two hack races for gentle- men are likely to be well patronized. The band of the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers has been engaged and an excellent tea will be served on the ground free of charge. Lieut. Col. Hill has kindly consented to act as judge, and if the weather is as fine as it is now, there is no doubt that half Cairo will be out at Mena House to see the fun. The Tramway Company has arranged for an extra service that day. Cars will run from Kasr-el-Nil tramway station evary 15 minutes. We regret to announce that Sir Elwin Palmer died yesterday morning at 6 15 o’clook at his residence at Cairo. In the first week of December, Sir Elwin and Lady Palmer left fora trip to Khartoum, where Miss Palmer had preceded them, Sir Elwin being desirous of seeing something of Mr. Leigh Hunt’s development work at the Atbara. On return- ing to Cairo he appeared to be ill and it was believed that he was suffering from a touch of sun-stroke. Bat it was soon recognised that the malady was enteric fever. It was thought that it was only a mild case and to all appearance ho w a so soon on the way to recovery that we were able to announce on the 10th inst. that he was making rapid progress towards convalescence and he could even see a few visitors. Two days afterward it was stated that he was so well that he hoped to be able to return to work in a few days’ time. But in enteric no patient can be considered out of danger until his convales- csnce is complete, for a relapse may even be worse than the primary fever, as was the case with Sir Elwin. Early last week he became rapidly worse and bulletins were posted daily on the door of his home at the National Bank. On Wednesday the doctors reported that the invalid had passed an easier night, on Thurs- day the news was not so comforting, Dr. Hess and Dr. Wildt, who were in attendance, reporting that he had somewhat lost strength, bat Friday’s bulletin showed that he had passed a better night and that his temperature had come down. Ou Saturday we stated that he had passed a bad night and that his heart had become weaker, and yesterday morning the end came. Sir Elwin was born on the 3rd March, 1852 and was therefore in his fifty-third year. He was the son of Mr. Edward Palmer and of Caroline, the daughter of Colonel Gonthorpe. He was educated at Lancing College and entered the Indian Financial Department in 1871. In 1881 he married Mary, the daughter of Major Herbert M. Clogstoun, V. C. He to be badly India until 1885, when he was appointed to accend Sir Gerald Fitzgerald as Director General of Appoints in Egypt. It is thanks to Sir Gerald Fitzgerald and Sir Edwin Palmer that Egypt p system of accounts which can bear companies with those of any other country in Europe. It is quite possible for the finances of a country to be badly administered, whilst, at the same time, the accounts may be in good order. On the other hand, it is impossible for the statesman or financier to seriously commence the work of fiscal and adminis- trative reform until, by the organisation of proper system of accounts, he is placed in possession of the true facts connected with the resources and expenditure of the State. One of the principal reasons why the early attempts made to regulate the financial condition of Egypt failed, was that the ac- counts were in a state of the utmost confu- sion. Owing to the efforts of Sir Elwin and his predecessor the Egyptian Accounts Department was thoroughly well organised and it would be difficult to exaggerate the importance of this achievement. In the summer of 1889 Sir Edgar Vincent resigned the post of Fi- nancial Adviser to the Egyptian Government to go to Constantinople as the Governor of the Imperial Ottoman Bank and Sir Elwin Palmer was appointed to succeed him in what was then and is still the corner-stone of English influence inside the Egyptian Ad- ministration. Sir Edgar Vincent left Egypt too soon to see the complete vindication of his financial policy, for during the six years of his administration he had been vigorously attacked as a juggler, who bad no real genius for grappling with the difficulties of finance, but only great skill in avoiding them. But Sir Elwin prudently and ably continued Sir Edgar’s system of administration, which has since then produced such brilliant results. In 1897 Sir Elwin was made a K. C. B. and in 1892 K.C.M.G. Iq September, 1898, he re- igned his position as Financial Adviser and Sir Eldon Gorst succeeded him. It is curious to note that the late Sir Clinton Dawkins severed his connection with the Finance Ministry almost at the same time as did Sir Elwin and both have died within a few months of one an other. The reason of Sir Elwin’s retirement from the service of the Egyptian Government was because he was appointed Governor of the National Bank of Egypt, which had been founded in that year. Previous to his retire- ment the Egyptian Government, acting on his advice, had sold the Daira Sanieh for £6,250,000 to Sir Ernest Cassel and a group of capitalists. The appointment of Sir Elwin Palmer to the governorship of the National Bank, coinciding with the disposal of the Daira Sanieh, caused some comment, especially when it was reported that the Government had in their possession a report of Crookshank Pacha, which declare I that the Daira was worth at the lowest com- putation £10,000,000. This subject has been revived in a, recent work on Egypt and Harari Pacha made the following declaration to the author in regard to Sir Elwin’s share in the matter. In justice to the memory of Sir Elwin we will reproduce what Harari Pacha said on the subject of the Daira deal :— The Financial Advisers have never made use of their position for their personal profit never, and Sir E. Palmer is the last man in the world to do so. Only he left the Government service to take up a brilliant position ; hence the trouble. Palmer was poor, why should he refuse such a good berth ? As to making him self responsible for the sale of the Dairs, the
thing is ridiculous, for, powerful as the Finan- cial Adviser may be, he can do nothing with- out, on the one hand, the approval of the Council of Ministers, and on the other, that of Lord Cromer. The idea that Lord Cromer would allow any suspicious deal whatever is so absolutely impossible that one does not stop even to consider it. The truth of the matter is, that the thing was done with the complete ap- proval of all the members of the Government Egyptian and English. No one could foresee that the estate would increase in value to such an extent, and in so short a space of time. £6 2'0,000 was considered a very good price for the Daira,’ and, besides, the buyer said, ‘I relieve you of all the trouble, all the anxiety all the expense which the estate has brought you. On my part I shall do the best I can for myself, and if at the finish of the business there is a profit, we shall share equally in it.’ It must be admitted that the offer seemed a good one, and one cannot blame the Adviser who recommended it and had it approved by the Ministers.” Mr. Raphael Suares, the well-known banker, has corroborated Harari Pacha’s statements that Sir Elwin had no arrangement with Sir Ernest Cassel. To the same author, here marked : —‘‘The thing won’t hold water,” and I can prove it. It was I, and not Ca°sel whom I had only seen once in my life and with whom I had had no business relations—it was I, I re- peat, who obtained, first, the concession for the founding of the National Bank and the option of purchasing the‘Daira’ for £6,0 0,000. Our house, Suares Brothers, not wishing to supply all the capital necessary, I left for London with the intention of offering a share in the business to one of my friends. On the boat, Mr. D., well-known in Egypt, advised me to immediately see Cassel, who, he believed, was anxious to enter into business relations with Egypt. I took his advice. When I offered 50 per cent. of the ‘Daira’ to Cassel he said: ‘I know nothing about this class of business, what do yon think it ought to yield ? I told him I looked for a profit of something over £1,000 000, when he said be would trust to me ; and the affair was concluded. The concession for the Bank seemed to please him more and he asked who should place at the head. It was then that I proposed Palmer, whose name, so well known as Financial Adviser, was bound to carry weight. You will see, therefore, that there was absolutely no arrangement between Sir E. Cassel and Sir E. Palmer.” It must be confessed that Sir Elwin was a very lucky man, and in both the high official posts which he occupied in the Egyptian Government the pioneer work had been under- taken by his predecessors. The Director-Generalship of Accounts was his first office in Egypt, which Sir Gerald Fitz- gerald had occupied from 1877 to 1885. Lord Cromer remarked in the recent Report, “Of the many Englishmen, who, by steady and unosten- tations work, hare rendered good service to the cause of Egyptian reform, there are few to whom greater merit con be assigned than Sir Gerald Fitzgerald, who first took this difficult task in hand, and who, by dint of untiring industry and perseverance, overcame all the obstacles which had to be encountered. Sir Gerald Fitzgerald did not take much part in the reforms themselves, but he performed work which was indispensable to others if the reforms were to be carried out.” During the years 1885- 1889 in which Sir Elwin occupied the post he was enabled to initiate those reforms which the industry of his predecessor had made possible, and the same luck fell to him when he was called upon to occupy the post of Financial Adviser. During the six years of his predecessor’s. Sir Edgar Vincent’s, administra- tion, the seed was sown and was steadily ripening- which under Sir Elwin Palmer and his successor yielded a bountiful harvest. “In many cases,” Lord Milner declares in his monu- mental work on Egypt “the reforms, which have borne the richest fruit, were due directly to Vincent’s initiative,” and he elsewhere re- marks that “Vincent will always be remembered as the most gifted and one of the most ener- getic of the little band of Englishmen who, under the presiding genius of Baring, rescued the finances by restoring the prosperity of Egypt.” Sir Elwin for the second time found his path made easy for him. He was as lucky in his career as a banker as he was as an official, for the National Bank was launched at the psycho- logical moment and was bound to be a success, as was the Agricultural Bank, of which he was chosen President in 1902. Besides his banking duties ha was greatly interested in many local companies of various sorts. He appears to have been esteemed by his fellow-directors for his shrewdness and business like capacities, and owing to the success of the many concerns he was interested in he was able to accumulate a large fortune in the few years that have followed his retirement from the post of Financial Adviser. Of all the Anglo-Egyptians who have benefited by the progress of Egypt, Sir Elwin was the foremost so far as wealth is concerned, and he must have left a very considerable estate. He could not be termed a popular man, and some of his business methods have been the subject of much criticism. Whether he administered the National Bank with that scrupulous regard for financial "tone,” such as should characterise the conduct of a great State Bank, it is not for us to decide. Criticism is very easy in Egypt and it is only natural that such a successful man as Sir Elwin was should have some enemies. But nothing succeeds like success, and nobody will venture to dispute that Sir Ernest Cassel made a wise choice when he selected Sir Elwin Palmer to guide the fortunes of the great banking institution which he has directed with such signal success. The operations on the Bourse this morning began as usual at 10 o’clock, when the Presi- dent of the Corbeille, Mr. D. Caralli, pro- nounced an eloquent discourse on the late banker and proposed that business should be suspended for half an hour as a sign of respect for his memory.
The salary of the Governor of the National Bank is £5,000 a year with residence equi- talent to a rental allowance of £1,000 a year. There are also many other perquisites such as a box at the opera, etc. Sir Elwin was insured in the New York Life Insurance Company for £2,000. The insurance was a 20 years endowment policy, expiring in next July. The National Bank of Egypt both at Cairo and Alexandria was closed to-day. The other Cairo banks will close this afternoon at 3 o’clock. There will be a memorial service this after- noon at All Saints’ Church, Cairo. The body is to be embalmed and taken to England. Among the orders, which the late financier received were the Grand Cordons of the Osmanieh and the Medjidieh. Sir Elwin belonged to the St. James’s Club in London. His recreations, as given in “Who’s Who” for 1906, are limited to golf and cycling.
EGYPTIAN ARMY. El Kaimakam Savile Bey, Senior Inspector of the Kassala Province, has been granted leave till April 26. El Bimbashi Blomfield, 1st Battalion, has been granted leave of absence until March 15. El Bimhashi Bridge, 11th Sudanese, resumed duty yesterday. The following officers have passed the intermediate Arabic examination: El Miralai Wilson Bey, Governor,. Sennar Province ; El Kaimakam Leigh, Bey, D.S.O., Acting Officer Commanding 4th Battalion ; El Kaimakam Rawson Bey, Acting Officer Commanding, 1 th Sudanese ; El Bimbashi Drake, Deputy Assis- tant Adjutant General ; El Bimbashi Parsons, Department of Supplies ; El Bimbashi Arden, 4th Battalion ; El Bimbashi Brakenridge, Medical Corps ; El Bimbashi Mayne, D.S.O. 13th Sudanese ; El Bimbashi Wise, 1st Batta- lion ; El Bimbashi Rome, Cavalry ; El Bim- bashi Hughes, Medical Corps. Captain C. C. Maud, D.S.O., Somersetshire Light Infantry, who has arrived in Egypt from England, has been taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army, and has been posted to the 11th Sudanese with the rank of Bimbashi. Lieutenant P. A Wilson, West India Regi- ment, is similarly taker on the strength of the Egyptian Army and posted to the 11th Sudanese with the rank of Bimbashi. El Kalmakam J. H. Rivers Bey, Medical Corpe, has resigned his commission in the Egyptian Army.
SUDAN NOTES (From our Correspondent). El Obeld, Kondofan, Jan. 10. Things are very quiet here at present, as most of the officers, both civil and military, are out in their various districts collecting taxes. etc. There is no polo going on, am afraid we shall not he able to play again until March or April, when some of the officers return here from their districts. We are having beautifully cool weather now, and the climate here at this time of year is quite perfect.
WALKER AND MEIMARACHI, LTD. The new board of this company is now com- posed of Messre, L. Carton de Wiart, Adolphe Cattaoni, Montagu Summers, F.Z.S., F R G.S., J. E. Drower, W. A. Loning, and Mr. Con- stantine Meimarachi, the managing director. In regard to the acquisition of the new site for this company’s business in Cairo, we think it our duty to note a remarkable example of the altruistic character of Mr. Constantine Meimarachi’s dealings. This gentleman lately purchased a site at the junction of Charia El Manakh and Charia El Madabegh, in the Ismailieh quarter of Cairo, at the price of L.E. 72,247. The property is of an area of 4816.5 square metres, of a rectangular shape, and through its central position in the Euro- pean business and residential quarter, it un- undoubtedly provides one of the finest and most suitable sites in Cairo for the erection of the new buildings. According to the report of Mr. Henry Hinks (Messrs. Barclay Hinks & Co., Cairo), a member of the Surveyors Institn- tion, London, dated the 16th January, 1906 the present value of this property is L.E. 96,330, or £20 per square metre. Now this property was bought by Mr. Meimarachi in his own name and he could, if he so wished, have disposed of it to the company at a profit to himself of £18 000. But he refused to take advantage of this and with a noble disinte restedness, which is very rare in Egypt, he has disposed of it to the company without a mil- lieme profit to himself. Such actions deserve to be noted when they occur as an example of high financial rectitude, and we take great pleasure in making the Egyptian public ac- quainted with Mr. Meimarachi’s altruism.

NILE-RED SEA RAILWAY. SPEECHES TO THE NATIVES BENEFITS OF THE NEW RAILWAY. (From our Special Correspondent). Port Sudan, Saturday, 12 p.m. The excellent speech delivered by Lord Cromer was translated into Hadendowa for the benefit of the large crowds of natives present by the Commandant of Police, and was received with cheers. Slatin Pacha’s speech to the natives con- tained the following passages : "I do not think any one of you is ignorant of the benefits to be derived from this railway which has now been established between here and Khartoum, especially you merchants, who can perfectly realise that to facilitate communications will entail much progress in trade. The success that will be attained by Suakin and Port Sudan will open more markets and increase the trade in both towns and will give the Arabs a good opportunity to sell their animals, batter, and milk at good prices.” Slatin Pacha also pointed out the openings there would be for labour and said that camel owners could use their camels for agricultural transport as in Egypt. The peroration to Slatin Pacha’s speech was as follows : The Government cannot offer you fortune, but guards your property and will protect you from aggression. The acquirement of wealth depends on your ability and activity. May God enlighten you and increase the fruits of prosperity and progress. You must believe in the Government’s good intentions and all its endeavours for your welfare. It is your duty to wish long life to Lord Cromer and the Governor-General, who are responsible for the administration of the country and ask God to guide them to do good and benefit the Sudan. Visit to the Harbour. After the inaugural ceremony had been concluded, a visit was paid to the works going on in the harbour. Lord Cromer, accompanied by the Governor-General, Sir Vincent Corbett, Sir Randolf von Slatin, Inspector General, Captain Phipps-Hornby, R. N., Colonel Mao- Cracken, Commanding 2nd Bn. R. Berkshire Regt., Major Hawker, Governor Red Sea Province. Captain Kennedy R. E., Director of Works, Mr. Higgins and Lieut. Kelly R. E., Resident Engineer, Port Sudan, were conveyed by the narrow gauge railway along the eastern arm of the harbour to inspect the works, as far as the temporary quays. At the landing stage of the temporary quay, Lord Cromer and party were conveyed across the harbour to the western side. From here Lord Cromer, the Governor General, Sir Kennedy, R. E, and Lieut. Kelly, R. E. wre conveyed by motor-car along the harbour to the Point, and then to visit the walls, return- ing via the hospital, and en route visiting the town, to the Mess Buildings. Afterwards the party returned to the landing stage, and went round the harbour, visiting the south-west arm, skirting the quarantine pro montory, thence to the special landing stage, Picket boats of H.M.S. Diana were in readi- ness, the leading boat conveying Lord Croxer, the Governor General, Sir Vincent Corbett. Captain Phipps Hornby, R.N., Captain Ken- nedy, R.E., and Major Hawker. On disembark- ing, Lord Cromor and party rejoined the train, and returned to the station enclosure. The impression formed after the visit was that Port Sudan was the cleanest and best laid out town on the Red Sea, and that the progress which has been achieved here during the last nine months is simply amazing. Lord Cromer, accompained by the Governor General and the other members of the party, on reaching the station, took train for Suakin the Egyptian Artillery firing a salute of 21 guns as the train lift the station. The British guard of honour and the officer in command returned to Khartoum by the same train. (From our Special Correspondent) Suakin, Saturday 1.35 p.m. Arrival at Suakin. 1 have just arrived at Suakin and am leaving at 1.45 for Khar oum where I expect to arrive at midday to-morrow. Lord Cromer, on arriving here, made an inspection of the condensors and afterwards inspected the harbour on board the launch Pioneer. His lordship afterwards left for the Atbara. He will spend the night at Gebeit (From our Special Correspondent) Atbara, Sunday, 12.30 p.m. Arrival at Atbara. I have just arrived at Atbara after a most interesting journey. I expect to arrive at Khartoum about 5 p.m. Lord Cromer arrives at Khartoum to-morrow. His lordship visited Sinkat, the scene of Tewfik Bay’s gallant defence in 1884, and slept at Gebeit. At Suakin yesterday I was officially in- formed that the Abou Hamed-Kareim v line had been completed. The Press party have been throughout splendidly treated, and thanks are especially due to Kaimakhm Owen Bey for his unfailing kindness and energy on our behalf.
OPINION OF LONDON PRESS. (Gazette's Special Service.) London, Monday, Jan. 29. All the London papers to-day contain enlo- gistic articles regarding Lord Cromer, in con- nection with the opening of the Nile-Red Sea Railway, and are full of appreciation of the work accomplished by Colonel Macaulay, con- trasting the state of affairs in D 85 and in 1906. They point to the moral triumphs achieved end look upon the Berber Railway as one of the wonders of the modem world.
PERSONAL AND SOCIAL. Mr. Machell’s brother-in-law, Count Glei- chen, who celebrated his forty-third birthday last week, is shortly leaving Berlin, where he is Military Attache at the British Embassy, an appointment he has held some time, and is going to Washington in the same capacity. Count Gleichen is a cousin of our King, and his godson, hearing the same name, Albert Edward. He is a keen soldier, has seen much good service, and is a successful author, his best known works being "With the Camel Corps up the Nile” and "With the Mission to Menelik.” Mr. MacMillan, the American millionaire, who has been such a frequent visitor of late to Egypt, is now living in British East Africa at the Juga farm, where he has all the comforts of his Mayfair home. Mr.MacMillan’s farm, which is at Donya Sabok, comprises all that the word "Ideal” implies. The electric light, coupled with an ice plant, and luxuries that only a great city affords, have been brought to the gate of the greatest game-shooting field in the world. We are asked to state that, owing to Sir Elwin Palmer’s death, Mrs. Dickson’s dance at the National Bank on February 7 will not take place. When the Leicestershires were quartered at Alexandria there was no more popular officer than Captain the Hon. Harold Brooke Hawke. The many friends he left in Egypt will therefore he interested to learn of his engagement to Anne, widow of Arthur J. J. Bamford, of Misterton, Leicestershire. The Chairman of the Daira Sanieh Company is unfortunate in losing Bast Bradford, and we venture to think East Bradford is unfortu- nate in losing him. Sir Vincent Caillard is a distinguished financier and clever business man, and his presence in the House could scarcely have resulted in anything but good. Sir Vincent is also Chairman of the London agency of the National Bank of Egypt and has been a good deal besides, since the 23rd of October, 1856. Then he was born, the son of a judge, and a good judve, too, who married the daughter of Lord Besoonfield's first cousin, and sent the son of the marriage to Etom, and "The Shop." "The Shop" turned out a Pollock Gold Medallist, who, thirty-one years ago, got his commission in the Royal Engineers. Other commissions, however, proved more attractive, and Sir Vincent sat upon a good many of mese. Then he took a torn with the Intelli- gence Department daring the Egyptian Cam- paign of 1882, the result of which was that the Ottoman Public Debt Council acquired a President, in 1883, and England, Holland and Belgium a financial representative at "Cons- tant.” From that onerous office Sir Vincent retired five or six years ago with all the honours and some other medals, and the Grand Cordons of the Osmanieh and the Medjidieh. Intermediat- ely, he has been of the brotherhood of the pen; and has written articles for other people’s news-papers and reviews. The following passengers left for the Nile by the P.S. Hatasoo on Friday : -Mrs. Morocco, Miss Long, Prof, and Mrs. Wittich, Mr. and Mrs. A. Grafton, Mrs. Farquhar, Miss Julia Simmons, Mrs. A. Nicholson, Mrs. A. Leah, Mr. and Mrs. G. Siddle, Miss Siddle, Mr. and Mrs. O. F. Steirt, Mr. and Mrs. Stringfellow, Mr. E Thorne, Mr. S. Thorne, Mr, Charles W. Wood, Miss Grace McRobb, Mr. W. H, Watney, Mr. W. Mitchell, Mr. and Mrs. Wistraner, Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Pres, Mr. W, Silverson, Mr. C. Silverson, Miss M. A. Silver- son, Mr. C. Silverson, Miss F. Field, Miss E. Field, Mrs. W. H. Jackson, Miss E. F. Jones, Mrs. L. J. Bacon, Mrs. Virginia Bodge, Mrs, M. L. Clarkson, Mrs M. A. Crosley, Mr. and Mrs. A. 8. Sawsrd, Mr. Prinsky, Mr. Lumley, Miss Holliday, Miss Croft, Mr. R. Talbot Kelly, Hon. R. H. Brand. The following were the passengers by the P. S. Prince Abbas, which left Shellal on Sunday : Mr. and Mrs. J. R. Corpe, Mr. H. Corpe, Mr. and Mrs. P. Fleury, Miss L. A. Millar, Miss P. Millar, Miss B Millar, Mr. C. Millar Mr H Millar, Miss G. Millar Mr. and Mrs. J. H. Cole, Miss Lucy N. Cole. Miss Leslie Chapin, Mrs. J. L. Murray, Miss P. Murray, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Ball, Miss Lu D. Sharpe, Miss Annie Stewart Evans, Miss Alice Evans, Miss Annie Hatfield, Dr. Alex- ander Oettinger, Mrs. Leila Oettinger, Mr. Emanuel Stockhausen, Mrs. Elisabeth Stock- hausen, Mr. J. Denniston Wilson, Baroness Uray, Baroness Vallyi, Mr. P. Gilardini, Mr. Bertero, Mr. C. W. Stork, Miss A. M. Ander- son, Miss M. C. Anderson, Mr. W. R Rober. The lafest arrivals at the Grand Hotel, Khartoum, are: the Hon Fred. Morgan, Miss Morgan, New York ; Vicomte de Saint Exrysery, Paris; Lady Chetwood, Capt. Baines, England.

TO-DAY’S TELEGRAMS. PEACE OF THE WORLD. FRANCE AND GERMANY’S PROTESTATIONS. Berlin, January 27. The President of the Reichstag eulogised the Emperor, whose ambition since his acces- sion had been to maintain the peace. He added that a powerful army would be able to over- throw whoever inconsiderately disturbed the peace of the world. (Havas) Paris, January 28. M. Etienne, on unveiling the monument to the aeronauts of the siege of Paris, stated that France was more than ever pacific, but in any ease French peace was dignified and strong. (Havas) MOROCCO CONFERENCE. PEACEFUL OUTLOOK. Algeciras. January 27. The delegates of the Powers, and notably M. Revoil, paid visits to Herr von Radowitz on the occasion of the Emperor William’s birth day. (Havas) Paris, January 28. At the banquet given on the Emperor Wil- liam’s birthday, Prince von Radolin said that the Morocco Conference would end in satis- factory results. (Havas) THE CRETAN IMBROGLIO. ITALIANS SEIZE CUSTOMS. Canea, January 28, The Italians have demanded an indemnity for the murder of the soldier killed on the 18th inst., and in consequence of the refusal of the Cretan Government to pay, they have seised three custom houses as a guarautee. (Reuter) SPANISH ROYAL MARRIAGE. A FAMILY GATHERING. Biarritz, January 28. King Alfonso and the Princess Ena are motoring daily together. (Reuter) San Sebastian, January 28. A general family gathering will take place here to-day, at which the Princess Ena will be presented to her future mother-in-law. (Reuter) MUTINY AT VLADIVOSTOK. ATTACK ON COMMANDANT. Vladivostok, January 27. On the 22nd inst. mutinous sailors seized rifles and ammunition. On the 23rd they marched to the commandant’s house and de- manded the release of prisoners. They were dispersed with quick-firers. On the 24th the insurgent artillerymen opened fire on the com- mandant with quick-firers and rifles, wounding him in the neck and chest. (Reuter) THE ELECTIONS. London, January 27. 882 Liberals, 42 Labourites, 153 Unionists, and 84 Nationalists have been elected. (R.) ENGLISHMAN’S ARREST IN RUSSIA. London, January 57. Mr. Davison, the manager of the Cotton Mills at Yarowalav, who was arrested on the charge of possessing literature of a liberal ten- dency, has been released. (Reuter) JAPAN’S ARMY AND NAVY. Tokio, January 28. A report submitted to the Diet places the expenditure of the Army at £99,000,000, and that for the Navy at £18,000,000. (Reuter) KARATHBODORY PACHA DEAD. Constantinople, January 28. Karatheodory Pacha is dead. (Reuter)

EGYPTIAN MINING. The feature of the Egyptian Mining market on the London Stock Exchange is a Bearsqneeze which appears to have occurred in Nile Valley shares. Heavy selling earlier in the week, aided by anticipations that the company may have to go through the throes of reconstruc- tion, brought the shares down to about 5s. But on Saturday week a distinct change came over the scone. The attempt to take in shares in connection with the settlement sufficed to show that they were in exceedingly short sup- ply, for the moment at any rate, and the price left off at about 9s., rising about 50 per cent during the morning as a result of the scramble to obtain them. The North Nile Valley is to suspend opera- tions until the Nile Valley mine at Um Garaiat is further developed. The directors of the former company, whose property is only a short distance away from Um Garaiat, intend to be guided by the results obtained at depth in the Nile Valley—a cautions and no doubt a wise policy. The secretary of the Nile Valley has issued a circular stating that it is hoped to hold the annual meeting this month, and adding that temporary arrangements have been made for providing the company with funds. In the report of the engineers mention is made of the lack of labour, owing to the religious festivals, but hope is expressed that a fall complement of workers will very shortly be again available.
VIOLIN RECITAL. Many people flocked to Signor Arrigo Serato’s violin recital, which took place at the Savoy Hotel on Friday afternoon after having been postponed from Wednesday evening. As usual there was an extraordinary small percen- tage of English among the audience, and we regret to say that some of these seemed to have mistaken the object of the entertainment, for they chatted unconcernedly to each other through several of the items. A certain amount of disappointment was felt at the announce- ment that the orchestral accompaniment was not available, as advertised, bat this feeling speedily wore off after Mme. M. Malateata had taken her place at the piano. She is a perfor- mer of no little note and her power of touch and brilliancy of execution are rare in a woman, while as an accompanist she keeps in most perfect sympathy with her partner. It was the first of Signor Serato’s concerts this season, but he made known his name in Cairo last year and the audience showed by the warmth of their greeting what pleasant recollections they held of his previous appear- ances. It was an infinite pleasure to listen to this great violinist. He succeeded in drawing a beautiful tone from his violin, his renderings were without exception fall of feeling, and the certainty of his bowing and accomplished technique excited general admiration. Signor Serato is certainly one of the greatest violinists of the present day and it must always be a pleasure to listen to him. His great qualities were especially evident in the concerto of Weiniawsky, the Perpetunm Mobile of Ries, and Jarnefeld’s Berceuse, and on the conclusion of Bach’s air on the fourth string he was accorded a perfect ovation, so enraptured was his audience. The whole concert was indeed a great success and we hope we shall hear Signor Serato several times more this season.

PRE-EMPTION. To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette. Sir,—Your correspondent “Capitalist” does not seem to consider the position which his proposal would create. The object intended to be secured by the law of preemption was what the English call the “amenities” of the property, the privacy consonant with the Moslem custom of secluding? women and like- wise of getting rid of an obnoxious neighbour by buying him out. Now suppose that two Europeans or a native and a European have contracted for the sale of property and that the would-be pre emptor is a native, according to the proposal of "Capitalist” the native would be excluded from exercising his right. Can “Capitalist” or anyone else tell me why in the name of reason or equity the native pre-emptor should be debarred from the exer- cise of this right, because one of the parties to the contract happens to be a European ? If I might be allowed to offer a suggestion I think that the difficulties raised by “Capital- ist” can be got over, as they very often are, by patting in the contract of sale, and there- fore on the register, so high a price as would preclude pre emption, which, it must be re- membered, has to be exercised within six months from date of sale. This practice would, in such case, be of benefit to the Treasury and cannot in any sense be considered as “contra bonos mores,” seeing that, firstly, the parties to the sale do not guarantee the accuracy of the statement as to price, nor has in reality anybody a right to enquire what was the arrangement between two private in- dividuals. Seeing that the Government has reduced the tax on registration from five to two per cent, the extra payment involved in the pretended increase of price would fall but lightly on the purchaser and can be regarded in the nature of an insurance. Cairo, Jan. 28th. Watani.
EGYPTIAN CIGARETTES. THE YEAR’S EXPORTS. The export of Egyptian cigarettes during the past year shows a decided increase over the previous year. In 1995 Egypt exported cigarettes to the amount of kilos 702,813 as against 620,470 in 1904, an increase of kilos 82,337. This is not, however, the same rate of increase as was the total for 1901 over 1903. when there was an increase of nearly 90,000 kilos over the latter year's exports. Germany was Egypt’s biggest customer in 1905, taking kilos 864,645, an increase of kilos 59,604. England came next with kilos 93,485, am increase of only kilos 1,715. Iu fact, England’s consumption of Egyptian cigarettes remains almost stationary and by a carious coincidence the amount she took last year corresponded exactly to a kilo with what she received in 1904, viz., kilos 96,485. The next largest customer was British India and England’s other Eastern possessions, which took kilos 74,364, then Austria-Hungary with kilos 50,998, China and the Far East with kilos 25,054,and France with kilos 22,718.

Notice is hereby given that holders of Bearer share warrants are entitled to a preferential allotment of one share for every two shares held by them of a new issue of 100,000 of £1 each. The above holders if desirous of availing themselves of the foregoing privilege must when making their applications produce their share warrants at the Company’s Office during business hours not later than the 30 h instant Copies of the prospectus and forms of appli- cation can be obtained at the Offices of the Company. By Order C. Sinder Hochstrasser, Secretary, Dated 26 January, 1906. 27,205-3 1 Cairo.
